Share.d:
Advanced Auto Brightness V3: A Professional-Grade Engine, Built Natively in Tasker

Frustrated with stock adaptive brightness that's either too slow, too jumpy, or just plain wrong? Advanced Auto Brightness (AAB) V3 is a ground-up redesign of how your screen should react to the world around it. It's a complete, 100% plugin-free replacement for Android's native system, giving you unparalleled control through a beautiful and intuitive command center.

This isn't just a set of rules; it's an intelligent engine designed for a smooth, natural, and completely personalized experience.

⭐ Why AAB V3 is the Definitive Upgrade ⭐

1. The All-in-One Command Center

Forget editing variables. V3 introduces a polished, multi-tabbed UI built with native Tasker scenes. It's your one-stop shop for configuration and real-time monitoring.

  • Effortless Navigation: A clean, tabbed interface separates settings into General (the main curve), Reactivity (sensor behavior), and Misc (limits and animations).
  • Live System Vitals: The panel constantly displays the current smoothed lux, the calculated target brightness, and the dynamic dead-zone, so you're never guessing what the engine is doing.

2. Live Graphing: See Your Changes, Instantly

The heart of the new UI is its live visualization engine. Before you save, you can see a precise graph of how your new settings will behave.

  • Visualize Your Curve: The Brightness Graph plots your custom light-to-brightness curve against a reference, so you can perfectly tune the response for every environment.
  • Tune Out the Jitter: The Reactivity Graph shows you the sensor's "dead-zone" on a logarithmic scale, allowing you to fine-tune the threshold to eliminate annoying flicker in any light level.
  • Master the Algorithm: See exactly how the dynamic smoothing factor responds to light changes with the Alpha Graph.

3. An Engine Built on Smarter Logic

AAB V3's backend is what truly sets it apart. It's designed for a stable and natural feel that stock brightness can't match.

  • Jitter-Free Stability: AABv3 uses a fully configurable, dynamic dead-zone that intelligently ignores minor sensor noise that would normally cause flickering.
  • Adaptive Smoothing: Brightness changes are smoothed using a dynamic alpha. This means large, intentional changes (walking outside) happen quickly, while small, insignificant flickers are smoothed into oblivion.
  • Dynamic Animations: Transitions are not a fixed speed. Small tweaks are slow and subtle, while large shifts are fast but always smooth, avoiding jarring jumps in brightness.

⚙️ Your 3-Step Setup Guide

  1. THE MOST IMPORTANT STEP: You MUST disable your phone's built-in "Adaptive Brightness" in the Android system settings. If you don't, AAB and the stock system will constantly fight for control.
  2. Grant Permission: Tasker will need the Modify System Settings permission to control brightness. The project includes a one-time helper to guide you through this.
  3. Launch & Configure: Run the Advanced Auto Brightness task from your launcher or Tasker. The control panel will appear. Flip the master switch in the General tab, and you're live! Explore the tabs and long-press any setting for a detailed explanation.

WebElement.Str:
Advanced Auto Brightness

About & License

Version 3.0

This project is a complete, native replacement for Android's stock auto-brightness system, built entirely within Tasker with no plugins required.

It was created by /u/v_uurtjevragen to provide a more intelligent, responsive, and customizable brightness experience.

Acknowledgments

This project wouldn't be possible without the incredible power and flexibility of Tasker, developed by João Dias.

The awesome graphs you see in the settings panels are powered by the Chart.js library.

WebElement.Str: Advanced Auto Brightness

Advanced Auto Brightness

Welcome to Advanced Auto Brightness

This project is a complete replacement for your phone's built-in auto brightness. Its goal is to provide a smoother, more intelligent, and completely customizable experience that adapts to light the way you want it to.

1. Getting Started: Two-Step Activation

Setting up is simple. There are only two things you need to do to get started.

  1. Activate the Service: In the General tab, flip the master switch on the top right. A persistent notification will appear, confirming that AAB is active. This action also automatically disables Android's native auto brightness system.
  2. Set Your Boundaries: Go to the Misc tab. Adjust the Min Brightness and Max Brightness sliders. This defines the absolute darkest and brightest your screen will ever get.
Tip: For phones with OLED screens, setting Min Brightness to a small value like 5 or 10 instead of 0 can prevent "black crush" (loss of detail in dark areas).

2. Understanding the Control Panel

The settings are organized into three main tabs, each with a specific purpose:

  • General: This tab defines the shape of your brightness curve. It answers the question: "What brightness level should I have for this amount of ambient light?"
  • Reactivity: This tab controls the behavior of the sensor. It answers the question: "When should I react to a change in light, and how sensitive should I be?"
  • Misc: This tab sets the rules and feel of the system. Here you'll find the master brightness limits, animation controls, and global fine-tuning adjustments.

3. Tuning Your Brightness Curve (General Tab)

This is where you design your core brightness response. The system uses a sophisticated three-part formula to give you precise control where it matters most.

  • Zone 1 (Darkness to Dim Light):
    • Zone 1 Scaling: This is your main control for low-light environments. Increase it to make the screen get brighter faster in the dark.
    • Zone 1 End: This sets the lux level where "dark" ends and "dim light" begins.
  • Zone 2 (Dim to Medium Light):
    • Zone 2 Scaling & Offset: These two work together to shape the curve for the most common indoor light levels. Adjust them and use the graph to see how they affect the transition from dark to dim.
  • Zone 3 (Bright Light):
    • This zone is handled automatically by a formula that smoothly approaches maximum brightness. This prevents the screen from becoming blindingly bright too quickly when you step outside.

4. Eliminating Flicker (Reactivity Tab)

A common issue with auto-brightness is jitter, annoying brightness fluctuations from minor sensor noise. This tab lets you eliminate it by creating a smart dead zone. The screen will only react when the light change is significant.

  • The Thresholds: Dark, Dim, and Bright Threshold control the size of this dead zone (as a percentage) for different light levels. Higher values mean more stability but less responsiveness.
  • The Curve: Curve Mid and Slope control how the dead zone smoothly transitions between the Dim and Bright Thresholdthreshold values you set.
Your Secret Weapon: Long-press any setting's label in any tab to see a detailed tooltip explaining exactly what it does!

5. Visualize Before You Apply: Use the Graphs!

Don't guess what your changes are doing. AAB provides real-time graphs to show you the exact impact of your settings before you save them.

  • Brightness Graph (General Tab): The Teal Line is your custom curve. The Yellow Line is a reference. Adjust your settings until the teal line matches your preference.
  • Reactivity Graph (Reactivity Tab): This visualizes your dead zone curve. It shows you how stable the system will be at different light levels.

6. Saving Your Work

Your adjustments are temporary until you save them.

  • Save & Apply: Saves your changes and immediately applies them.
  • Reset tab defaults: Reverts the settings on the current tab to their original values.
  • Exit: Closes the control panel without saving any changes you've made.

Enjoy your new intelligent auto brightness!

Action.Str: Sets the highest brightness level the screen will ever use. Can be used to cap the max brightness to save battery.

Action.Str: The dynamic scale engine requires location access in order to properly acquire times for solar events in your location.

Action.label: This modifier will span from -1 to +1 following a circadian rhythm!

Action.Str: Easter Egg unlocked! EXPERIMENTAL settings now available. Tap Experiment to open.
Controls how wide the scale shifts over the day. E.g. 20 results in a multiplier ranging from 0.8 to 1.2
Easter Egg locked! Experimental settings no longer available. Tap Misc to open.
⚠️ Not saved! One or more values have not been set!
Controls the sharpness of the transition curve between the day and night scale factors. Higher values create a more rapid change around solar noon and midnight.
⚠️ One or more values haven't been set. Can't be saved!
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!
Select the date and/or location for the sunrise/sunset time fetching. If unset, the task will use today's sunrise/sunset (highly recommended!)
Enables or disables the entire experimental circadian scaling feature. When disabled, the simpler 'Scale' and 'Offset' multipliers from the Misc tab are used instead.
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!
⚠️ Graph might be non-sensical due to scale transition factor being greater than 1.
Please be patient. Generating the graph might take a few seconds.
Adjusts the duration of the transition between the daytime and nighttime scale factors. A higher value creates a longer, more gradual blend around sunrise and sunset.
⚠️ Graph invalid. Negative values in calculated cells. Won't be drawn!
Controls how quickly brightness rises in dim light. Recommended: 1 to 5
Hinge point to enable smooth transition from zone 1 (dark) to zone 2 (dim to medium).
Higher values give a major boost in medium light. Recommended: 3 to 10
Subtle but powerful "offset" for the midrange curve. Lower values make the transition from dark to dim light more gradual and smooth. Recommended: -300 to %aab_zone1end.
Zone 2 Offset cannot exceed Zone 1 End!
Sets the lux level where 'dim light' ends and 'indoor light' begins. Typically for moving from a dark room to a lit one.
Hinge point to enable smooth transition from zone 2 (dim to medium) to zone 3 (bright).
Sets the lux level where 'indoor light' ends and 'bright outdoor light' begins. Affects the transition when going outside.
Zone 2 End cannot be smaller than Zone 1 End!
Zone 2 Offset cannot exceed Zone 1 End!
Current light sensor reading after smoothing and other formulas are applied and the corresponding brightness level.

Current throttle is a time based gatekeeper for the main brightness loop.
α is used in exponential moving average calculation: smoothed sensor read=(new raw read×α)+(old smoothed read×(1-α))
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Can't be saved!
To work correctly, this app needs permission to "Display over other apps".
To allow this app to modify system settings (e.g. brightness changes), please grant “Modify system settings” permission

Action.Str: Did you manage to grant the notification permission?
Permission not granted. You can grant via Misc > Info > Re-check permissions.
Please be patient. Generating the graph might take a few seconds.
Sets the brightness level (%AAB_MinBright-%AAB_MaxBright) where the high-end compression is centered. This is the 'knee' of the curve. Lower values will start tapering the scale factor earlier.
Use a quick settings tile set to position 3 (Preferences > Action > Quick settings task > _QSToggleAABService).
⚠️ Taper midpoint cannot exceed current maximum brightness (%AAB_MaxBright)
Controls the slope of the dynamic range compression.
Displays the current (un)compressed scale factor based on the time of day, (the current screen brightness) and your 'Spread' setting.
Please check notification(s) to grant permission(s)!
Notification permission not granted. You can grant via the Misc > Info > Re-check permissions.
Will no longer trust low accuracy sensor readings.
Will now trust low accuracy sensor readings.
Brightness is only changed when the change in lux exceeds this threshold, i.e. the lux measurements need to be outside of the dead zone. This prevents jitter.
Not saved! One or more values have not been set!

The log-transformed lux level where the system is most sensitive to change. Think of it as the 'center point' of the reactivity curve.
E.g. 10^%AAB_ThreshMidpoint equals %aab_10xthreshmidpoint lx
Minimum wait cannot exceed maximum wait!
Maximum wait cannot be lower than minimum wait!
Loops: %loops, wait time: %wait ms Target brightness: %calculated_brightness_smooth Maximum target: %max_target Minimum target: %min_target

Action.label: animation_loop
Shows 1 decimal point in the scene below 10 lux.
Setting the debug level to 1 skips smoothing and next steps altogether!

After a brightness animation ends, the throttle is stuck at a low value (in unchanging light). This "unsticks" the throttle and prevents additional runs of the Evaluate Light Change task. However, that profile shouldn't run anyway due to the boolean logic in the profile triggers. Perhaps this profile and task are redundant.

Action.Str: Manual brightness override detected or Android's auto-brightness enabled. The service is now paused. Tap the notification to continue the service.
Brightness manually set or Android auto brightness enabled. Expand notification and tap "tap here to resume."
Brightness manually set or Android auto brightness enabled. Expand notification and tap "tap here to resume."
The reactivity level in complete darkness. A higher value means the brightness is more stable and less 'jumpy' in very dark rooms.
The baseline reactivity for most situations. A lower value makes the system more responsive to small decreases in light.
The baseline reactivity for bright, outdoor light. A higher value prevents tiny shadows (like your hand) from causing annoying brightness dips.
Controls how quickly the reactivity changes as you move from dim to bright light. Higher value = more abrupt transition.
Sets the lowest brightness level the screen will ever use. Recommended to be > 0 on OLED screens to avoid 'black crush'.
The number of steps in a brightness change animation. More steps create a smoother, but slightly slower, transition.
The shortest time (in milliseconds) between animation steps. Controls how fast large brightness changes feel.
The longest time (in milliseconds) between animation steps. Controls how slowly small, subtle brightness changes occur.
Enable this ONLY if auto-brightness seems unresponsive on your device. This may cause brightness to become unstable or flicker.
A global multiplier for the entire brightness curve. Use it to adjust the overall contrast. >1 stretches the curve brighter, <1 compresses it dimmer.
A simple brightness boost or cut. This value is added to (or subtracted from) the final brightness across all light levels.
Controls how much to smooth out sensor readings. Higher values react faster to small light changes, but may increase jitter. Lower values are more stable, but might feel sluggish.
Delta factor cannot be 0 or lower! Field not stored.
⚠️ Invalid brightness settings. Negative values in calculated cells. Can't be saved!

Action.label: End of the Zone where Formula 1 applies.
End of the Zone where Formula 2 applies.
This is the 'Scaling' factor for the Zone 1 formula.
This is the 'Start Brightness' constant for Zone 2.
This is the 'Scaling' factor for Zone 2.
This is the 'Steepness/Offset' factor for Zone 2.
This is the Zone 1 Transition Lux, used in the Zone 2 formula.
This is the 'High-Lux Alignment Factor' for Zone 3.
Caution: Brightness of 0 may be unreadable on some devices. Test in a dark room.
This acts as a multiplier for the entire curve.
This adds a constant to the curve and thereby 'lifts' the curve upwards.
The maximum number of animation steps to perform for the Smooth Brightness Transition task.
Default set to allow %AAB_MaxSteps × AAB_MaxWait to finish.
Stability in darkness (at 0 lux)
Sensitivity in dim light (lower bound asymptote)
Sensitivity in bright light (upper bound asymptote)
Reactivity Aggressiveness
Midpoint of change (log lux)

Action.Str: Defaults initialized. To finish setup, please turn your screen off and back on.

Action.label: This flag prevents this task from being flagged as a manual brightness change.
Safe fallback if the sensor failed to return a proper reading.
This skips animations during Map Lux to Brightness
This skips smoothing and ensures the new value is set with a maximum alpha. Passed as %par2 into Map Lux To Brightness task.
